RD3-team1={{flagdeco|US}} '''[[Bobby Fischer]]''' | RD3-score1='''6½''' | RD3-team2={{flagdeco|URS}} [[Tigran Petrosian]] | RD3-score2=2½ }} Fischer's victory earned him the right to challenge reigning champion Spassky for the title. ==1972 World Championship match== ===Schedule and results=== The match was played as the best of 24 games, with wins counting 1 point and draws counting ½ point, and would end when one of the players scored 12½ points.[[FIDE]] Article 7, Rule 8, reproduced in Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 204 If the match ended in a 12–12 tie, the defending champion (Spassky) would retain the title.[[FIDE]] Article 7, Rule 6, reproduced in Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 204 The first [[time control]] was 40 moves in 2½ hours.[[FIDE]] Article 7, Rule 9b, reproduced in Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 204 Three games per week were scheduled.[[FIDE]] Article 7, Rule 9a, reproduced in Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 204 Each player was entitled to three postponements for medical reasons during the match.[[FIDE]] Article 7, Rule 10, reproduced in Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 204Gligorić 1972, p. 86 Games were scheduled to start on Sunday, Tuesday, and Thursday.Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 59 If a game was adjourned, it was to be continued the next day. Saturday was a rest day. Fischer insisted that a [[Staunton chess set]] from [[Jaques of London]] be used. The [[chessboard]] had to be remade at Fischer's request.Edmonds & Eidinow 2004, pp. 163–64 The match was covered throughout the world. Fischer became a worldwide celebrity, described as the [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]] of chess. His hotel received dozens of calls each day from women attracted to him, and Fischer enjoyed reading the numerous letters and telegrams that arrived with compliments or criticisms.{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EVUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&rview=1&pg=PA40#v=onepage&q&f=true | title=Bobby is Not a Nasty Kid | work=Life | date=1972-08-11 | accessdate=March 25, 2013 | author=Darrach, Brad | pages=40}} Excitement grew as the match was postponed and people questioned whether Fischer would appear. Previously, he had come to the airport and, surrounded by reporters, left. The combination of "Will he play?" and "American versus Russian" created excitement throughout the world. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center" |+World Chess Championship Match 1972 |- ! !! Points |- | align=left | {{flagathlete|[[Boris Spassky]]|USSR}} | 2660 || 1 ||style="background:black; color:white"| 1 || 0 ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || 0 ||style="background:black; color:white"| 0 || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| 0 || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| 0 || 1 ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || 0 ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || 0 || 8½ |- | align=left | {{flagathlete|'''[[Bobby Fischer]]'''|USA}} | '''2785''' ||style="background:black; color:white"| 0 || 0 ||style="background:black; color:white"| 1 || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| 1 || 1 ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || 1 ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || 1 || style="background:black; color:white"| 0 || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| 1 || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| ½ || ½ ||style="background:black; color:white"| 1 || '''12½''' |} ===Games=== {{AN chess|pos=secleft}} ====Game 1: Spassky–Fischer, 1–0 (Nimzo-Indian) {{anchor|Game 1}}==== The opening was a placid [[Nimzo-Indian Defense]], and after 17...Ba4 the game was even ([[Miroslav Filip|Filip]]).Matanović 1991 (Vol E), p. 312, n. 28 After a series of piece [[Exchange (chess)|exchanges]] the position in the diagram was reached after 29.b5. It appeared to be a {{chessgloss|dead draw|dead-drawn}} [[chess endgame|ending]], and no one would have been remotely surprised if the players had [[draw by agreement|agreed to a draw]] here.Evans & Smith 1973, p. 26Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 82Alexander 1972, p. 86 {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 1''' | | | | | |kd| | |pd|pd| | | | |pd|pd | | | |bd|pd|pd| | | |pl| | | | | | | | | | | | | | |pl| | |kl|pl| | | | | | | | |pl|pl|pl | | |bl| | | | | |Fischer played 29...Bxh2{{chesspunc|?}} }} Shockingly, Fischer played 29...Bxh2{{chesspunc|?}},[[Garry Kasparov]] (2004b), [[Max Euwe]] & [[Jan Timman]] (2009), Dmitry Plisetsky & Sergey Voronkov (2005), [[Svetozar Gligoric]] (1972), and [[C.H.O'D. Alexander]] (1972) all give this move one question mark (a bad move but not a [[Blunder (chess)|blunder]]). [[Larry Evans]] & [[Ken Smith (chess)|Ken Smith]] (1973), and Richard Roberts, [[Harold C. Schonberg|Harold Schonberg]], [[Israel Albert Horowitz|Al Horowitz]] & [[Samuel Reshevsky]] (1972) give it "{{chesspunc|?!}}" (a dubious move). a move that few players would consider in light of the obvious 30.g3, trapping the [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]]. In exchange for the lost bishop, Black is only able to obtain two [[Pawn (chess)|pawns]] (see [[chess piece relative value]]). [[Svetozar Gligorić|Gligorić]], [[Garry Kasparov|Kasparov]] and other commentators have suggested that Fischer may have miscalculated, having planned 30...h5 31.Ke2 h4 32.Kf3 h3 33.Kg4 Bg1, but overlooking that 34.Kxh3 Bxf2 35.Bd2 keeps the bishop trapped.Kasparov 2004b, p. 434Gligorić 1972, p. 34 [[Anatoly Karpov]] suggested that Spassky was afraid of Fischer and wanted to show that he could draw with the white pieces, while Fischer wanted to disprove that as the game headed for a stale draw.Karpov 1990, p. 100 Owing to unusual features in the position, Fischer had good drawing chances despite having only two [[Pawn (chess)|pawns]] for the bishop.[[Robert Byrne (chess player)|Robert Byrne]] wrote, "The wonder is that, even though he now loses the bishop for two pawns, he would have been able to draw had it not been for his later mistakes." Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 83 But the position became hopeless after he made at least one more bad move before the {{chessgloss|adjournment}}, which took place after move 40.Mednis 1997, pp. 275–76 Fischer could still have drawn the game with the correct 39th or 40th move.Gligorić 1972 (p. 34), Alexander 1972 (p. 86), and Evans & Smith 1973 (p. 29) all give Fischer's 40th move as a bad move, stating that he could still have drawn with the correct 40th move. More recent books by Kasparov 2004b (p. 435) and Plisetsky & Voronkov 2005 (p. 443) give Fischer's 39th move as weak, claiming that his last opportunity to draw the game was with 39...e5! Mednis 1997 (pp. 274–76) says that Fischer's 37th move was bad, and thinks he missed a draw with 37...a6. Euwe & Timman 2009 (pp. 55–57), citing analysis of [[Friðrik Ólafsson]] and independently [[Jon Speelman]] say that Fischer could have forced a draw after 36.a4? with 37...a6 or with 39...e5.

Speelman analyzed the position in depth in his 1980 book, ''Analysing the Endgame'', pp. 74–80, taking into account previous analysis by others. He states that 29...Bxh2 was a bad move, giving White excellent winning chances without any compensating chances for Black. But the position was not lost after that move; only after two more errors (37...Ke4?! and 39...f5?) was Black was clearly lost. He {{chessgloss|resigned}} on move 56. {{block indent |1=[[Nimzo-Indian Defense]], [[Nimzo-Indian Defence#4...0-0 Main line|Main Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' E56)
1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3 Bb4 5.e3 0-0 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Ba5 9.Ne2 dxc4 10.Bxc4 Bb6 11.dxc5 Qxd1 12.Rxd1 Bxc5 13.b4 Be7 14.Bb2 Bd7 15.Rac1 Rfd8 16.Ned4 Nxd4 17.Nxd4 Ba4 18.Bb3 Bxb3 19.Nxb3 Rxd1+ 20.Rxd1 Rc8 21.Kf1 Kf8 22.Ke2 Ne4 23.Rc1 Rxc1 24.Bxc1 f6 25.Na5 Nd6 26.Kd3 Bd8 27.Nc4 Bc7 28.Nxd6 Bxd6 29.b5 (''diagram'') Bxh2 30.g3 h5 31.Ke2 h4 32.Kf3 Ke7 33.Kg2 hxg3 34.fxg3 Bxg3 35.Kxg3 Kd6 36.a4 Kd5 37.Ba3 Ke4 38.Bc5 a6 39.b6 f5 40.Kh4 f4 41.exf4 Kxf4 42.Kh5 Kf5 43.Be3 Ke4 44.Bf2 Kf5 45.Bh4 e5 46.Bg5 e4 47.Be3 Kf6 48.Kg4 Ke5 49.Kg5 Kd5 50.Kf5 a5 51.Bf2 g5 52.Kxg5 Kc4 53.Kf5 Kb4 54.Kxe4 Kxa4 55.Kd5 Kb5 56.Kd6 {{chessAN|1–0}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044722 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 1 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} ====Game 2: Fischer forfeits {{anchor|Game 2}}==== After his loss Fischer made further demands on the organizers, including that all cameras be removed. When they were not, he refused to appear for game 2, giving Spassky a default win. His appeal was rejected. Karpov speculates that this forfeited game was actually a masterstroke on Fischer's part, a move designed specifically to upset Spassky's [[equanimity]]. With the score now 2–0 in Spassky's favor, many observers believed that the match was over and Fischer would leave Iceland, and, indeed, Fischer looked to board the next plane out, only to be dissuaded by his second, William Lombardy."Fischer lodged a formal protest [over the second-game-forfeit] less than six hours after the forfeiture. It was overruled by the match committee... Everyone knew that Fischer wouldn't accept it lightly. And he didn't. His instant reaction was to make a reservation to fly home immediately. He was dissuaded by Lombardy, but it seemed likely that he'd refuse to continue the match unless the forfeit was removed." Brady 2011, p. 193 His decision to stay in the match was attributed by some to another phone call from Kissinger and a deluge of cablegrams.Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, pp. 99–100Brady 2011, pp. 194–95 Owing to his sporting spirit and respect and sympathy for Fischer, Spassky agreed to play the third game in a small room backstage, out of sight of the spectators. According to [[Pal Benko]] and [[Burt Hochberg]], this concession was a psychological mistake by Spassky.They write that it "had a costly psychological effect on Spassky". [[Pal Benko]] and [[Burt Hochberg]], ''Winning with Chess Psychology'', David McKay, 1991, p. 87, {{ISBN|0-8129-1866-5}}; Benko and Hochberg also quote Spassky as saying after the match, "My acceding to Fischer's groundless demand to play in a closed room was a big psychological mistake." ''Id.'', p. 92 ====Game 3: Spassky–Fischer, 0–1 (Modern Benoni) {{anchor|Game 3}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 3''' |rd| |bd|qd|rd| |kd| |pd|pd| |nd| |pd|bd|pd | | | |pd| |nd|pd| | | |pd|pl| | | | | | | | |pl| | | | | |nl| | | | | |pl|pl|ql|nl|bl|pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl| | |rl|kl| |Fischer played 11...Nh5{{chesspunc|!?}} }} This game proved to be the turning point of the match. After 11.Qc2 (''diagram''), Fischer demonstrated his acute intuitive feel for the position with 11...Nh5{{chesspunc|!?}}—a seemingly {{chessgloss|antipositional}} move allowing White to shatter Black's {{chessgloss|kingside}} [[pawn structure]], but Fischer's assessment that his kingside {{chessgloss|attack}} created significant {{chessgloss|counterplay}} proved correct.Evans & Smith 1973, p. 40 Surprised by Fischer's {{chessgloss|theoretical novelty|novelty}}, Spassky did not react in the best way. Instead of 15.Bd2, 15.Ne2!? was possible ([[Igor Zaitsev|Zaitsev]]),Matanović 1996 (Vol A), p. 481, n. 26 or 15.f3 to prevent ...Ng4.Alexander 1972, p. 89 In particular, Spassky's 18th move, weakening the light squares, was a mistake.Evans & Smith 1973, pp. 40–42 The game was {{chessgloss|adjournment|adjourned}}, and Spassky resigned the next day upon seeing that Fischer had sealed the best move, 41...Bd3+{{chesspunc|!}} The win was Fischer's first ever win against Spassky.Gligorić 1972, p. 41 {{block indent |1=[[Modern Benoni|Modern Benoni Defense]], [[Modern Benoni#7.Nf3 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0: Classical Main Line|Classical Main Line]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' A77)
1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 c5 4.d5 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.Nc3 g6 7.Nd2 Nbd7 8.e4 Bg7 9.Be2 0-0 10.0-0 Re8 11.Qc2 (''diagram'') Nh5 12.Bxh5 gxh5 13.Nc4 Ne5 14.Ne3 Qh4 15.Bd2 Ng4 16.Nxg4 hxg4 17.Bf4 Qf6 18.g3 Bd7 19.a4 b6 20.Rfe1 a6 21.Re2 b5 22.Rae1 Qg6 23.b3 Re7 24.Qd3 Rb8 25.axb5 axb5 26.b4 c4 27.Qd2 Rbe8 28.Re3 h5 29.R3e2 Kh7 30.Re3 Kg8 31.R3e2 Bxc3 32.Qxc3 Rxe4 33.Rxe4 Rxe4 34.Rxe4 Qxe4 35.Bh6 Qg6 36.Bc1 Qb1 37.Kf1 Bf5 38.Ke2 Qe4+ 39.Qe3 Qc2+ 40.Qd2 Qb3 41.Qd4 Bd3+ {{chessAN|0–1}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044727 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 3 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 4: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (Sicilian Sozin) {{anchor|Game 4}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 4''' |bd| | | | |rd| | | | | | | |pd|kd| | | | | |pd| | | |pd| |bd| |qd| |pd| | | |bl|nl| | |ql| |pl| | | | | | |pl | |pl|pl| | | |pl| | | | |rl| | | |kl |Position after 29.Nd4 }} The match resumed with this game on the main hall stage per Spassky's request, but without TV cameras per Fischer's request. Fischer as White played the Sozin Attack against Spassky's Sicilian Defense. Spassky [[sacrifice (chess)|sacrificed]] a pawn, and after 17...Bxc5+ had a slight advantage ([[John Nunn|Nunn]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 438, n. 72 Spassky developed a strong kingside attack, but failed to convert it into a win,Gligorić 1972, pp. 43–46 the game ending in a draw. {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence#Classical Variation|Sozin Attack]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B88)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 Nc6 6.Bc4 e6 7.Bb3 Be7 8.Be3 0-0 9.0-0 a6 10.f4 Nxd4 11.Bxd4 b5 12.a3 Bb7 13.Qd3 a5 14.e5 dxe5 15.fxe5 Nd7 16.Nxb5 Nc5 17.Bxc5 Bxc5+ 18.Kh1 Qg5 19.Qe2 Rad8 20.Rad1 Rxd1 21.Rxd1 h5 22.Nd6 Ba8 23.Bc4 h4 24.h3 Be3 25.Qg4 Qxe5 26.Qxh4 g5 27.Qg4 Bc5 28.Nb5 Kg7 29.Nd4 (''diagram'') Rh8 30.Nf3 Bxf3 31.Qxf3 Bd6 32.Qc3 Qxc3 33.bxc3 Be5 34.Rd7 Kf6 35.Kg1 Bxc3 36.Be2 Be5 37.Kf1 Rc8 38.Bh5 Rc7 39.Rxc7 Bxc7 40.a4 Ke7 41.Ke2 f5 42.Kd3 Be5 43.c4 Kd6 44.Bf7 Bg3 45.c5+ {{chessAN|½–½}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044365 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 4 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 5: Spassky–Fischer, 0–1 (Nimzo-Indian) {{anchor|Game 5}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 5''' | | | | | |kd| | | | | |bd| | |pd| | |pd| | | | |qd|pd |pd| |pd|pl|pd| |pd| |pl| |pl| |pl|nd| | | | |pl|ql| | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl | | | |bl|bl| |kl| |Spassky played 27.Qc2{{chesspunc|??}} }} Game 5 was another Nimzo-Indian, this time the Hübner Variation: 4.Nf3 c5 5.e3 Nc6 6.Bd3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6.Gligorić 1972, p. 48 Fischer rebuffed Spassky's attempt to attack; after 15...0-0 the game was even ([[András Adorján|Adorján]]).Matanović 1991 (Vol E), p. 251, n. 67 Fischer obtained a blocked position where Spassky was saddled with weak pawns and his {{chessgloss|bishop pair}} had no prospects.Gligorić 1972, pp. 47–49 After 26 moves, Spassky faced the position in the diagram, in which he blundered with 27.Qc2{{chesspunc|??}}, and resigned after Fischer's 27...Bxa4! After 28.Qxa4 Qxe4, Black's dual threats of 29...Qxg2{{chessAN|#}} and 29...Qxe1# would decide; alternatively, 28.Qd2 (or 28.Qb1) Bxd1 29.Qxd1 Qxe4 30.Qd2 a4 wins. {{block indent |1=[[Nimzo-Indian Defense]], [[Nimzo-Indian Defence#4...c5|Hübner Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' E41)
1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Bb4 4.Nf3 c5 5.e3 Nc6 6.Bd3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 8.e4 e5 9.d5 Ne7 10.Nh4 h6 11.f4 Ng6 12.Nxg6 fxg6 13.fxe5 dxe5 14.Be3 b6 15.0-0 0-0 16.a4 a5 17.Rb1 Bd7 18.Rb2 Rb8 19.Rbf2 Qe7 20.Bc2 g5 21.Bd2 Qe8 22.Be1 Qg6 23.Qd3 Nh5 24.Rxf8+ Rxf8 25.Rxf8+ Kxf8 26.Bd1 Nf4 (''diagram'') 27.Qc2 Bxa4 0–1{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044723 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 5 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} Thus Fischer had drawn level (the score was now 2½–2½), although FIDE rules stipulated that the champion retained the title if after 24 games the match ended in a tie. After game 5, Fischer hinted to Lombardy about a surprise he had in store for game 6."Despite the victory [in game 5], neither Bobby nor I was satisfied with the outcome of his king pawn sally in Game Four. "Don't worry. Sunday I will play something that will make you very happy..."[http://bobbyfischer.net/bobby07.html "A Mystery Wrapped in an Enigma"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150902042455/http://bobbyfischer.net/bobby07.html |date=2015-09-02 }} [[William Lombardy]], January 21, 1974, Bobby-Fischer.net {{clear}} ====Game 6: Fischer–Spassky, 1–0 (QGD Tartakower) {{anchor|Game 6}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 6''' | | |rd| | |qd|kd| |rd| | |nd| | |pd| |pd| | | |pd| | |pd | | |pd|pd| | | | | | | | |pl| | | |ql| | | | | | | |pl|pl| | |bl|pl|pl|pl | | |rl| | |rl|kl| |Position after 20.e4{{chesspunc|!}} }} Before the match began, the Soviet team that had been training Spassky debated about whether Fischer might play an opening move different from his usual 1.e4."Krogius: Of course, we ourselves tried to forecast the direction of the American grandmaster's preparations. I remember that repeated suggestions were made about possible changes in Fischer's style, and in particular his opening repertoire." Plisetsky & Voronkov 2005, p. 308. "But when the question was raised as to whether 1.d4 or 1.c4 could be expected of Fischer, Spassky replied: 'Let's not bother with such nonsense – I'll play the [Tartakower] Defence. What can he achieve?...{{'"}}Plisetsky & Voronkov 2005, p. 308. Fischer played 1.c4 (instead of 1.e4) for only the third time in a serious game.The two prior occasions were at the 1970 Palma de Mallorca [[Interzonal]], when Fischer played 1.c4 against [[Lev Polugaevsky]] and [[Oscar Panno]]. Gligorić 1972, p. 52 With 3.d4 the game [[Transposition (chess)|transposed]] to the [[Queen's Gambit]], surprising many who had never seen Fischer play the White side of that opening. In fact, he had previously openly condemned it. Spassky played Tartakower's Defense (7...b6), his favorite choice in many tournaments and a line with which he had never lost.Gligorić 1972, pp. 51–52 After 14.Bb5!? (introduced in Furman–Geller, Moscow 1970),D. Marović, ''Play the Queen's Gambit'', Maxwell Macmillan Chess, 1991, p. 130, {{ISBN|1-85744-016-1}} Spassky responded with 14...a6?!. Geller had previously shown Spassky 14...Qb7!, the move with which Geller later beat [[Jan Timman]] at Hilversum 1973, but Spassky apparently forgot about it.After Furman–Geller, [[Semyon Furman]], Geller, Spassky, and [[Eduard Gufeld]] analyzed the game, and "Geller analyzed a plan associated with material sacrifices that would begin with the move 14...Qb7!" Geller was also one of Spassky's {{chessgloss|seconds}} for the match, and "during the preparation for the match they studied this position" (after 14.Bb5). Eduard Gufeld, "Inventors and Novelty-Makers", ''[[Chess Life]]'', March 2001, p. 26 After 21.f4 Fischer had the upper hand ([[Vlastimil Hort|Hort]]).Matanović 1976 (Vol D), p. 273, n. 69 After 26.f5, White had a crushing attack. {{block indent |1=[[Queen's Gambit Declined]], [[Queen's Gambit Declined#QGD Main Variations|Tartakower Defense]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' D59)
1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.d4 Nf6 4.Nc3 Be7 5.Bg5 0-0 6.e3 h6 7.Bh4 b6 8.cxd5 Nxd5 9.Bxe7 Qxe7 10.Nxd5 exd5 11.Rc1 Be6 12.Qa4 c5 13.Qa3 Rc8 14.Bb5 a6 15.dxc5 bxc5 16.0-0 Ra7 17.Be2 Nd7 18.Nd4 Qf8 19.Nxe6 fxe6 20.e4 (''diagram'') d4 21.f4 Qe7 22.e5 Rb8 23.Bc4 Kh8 24.Qh3 Nf8 25.b3 a5 26.f5 exf5 27.Rxf5 Nh7 28.Rcf1 Qd8 29.Qg3 Re7 30.h4 Rbb7 31.e6 Rbc7 32.Qe5 Qe8 33.a4 Qd8 34.R1f2 Qe8 35.R2f3 Qd8 36.Bd3 Qe8 37.Qe4 Nf6 38.Rxf6 gxf6 39.Rxf6 Kg8 40.Bc4 Kh8 41.Qf4 1–0{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044366 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 6 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} After this game, Spassky joined the audience in applauding Fischer's win.Gligorić 1972, p. 55 This astounded Fischer, who called his opponent "a true sportsman".{{r|darrach19720811}} "Lombardy was ecstatic: 'Bobby has played a steady, fluent game, and just watched Spassky make horrendous moves. Spassky has not met a player of Bobby's genius and caliber before, who fights for every piece on the board; he doesn't give in and agree to draws like the Russian grandmasters. This is a shock to Spassky.{{' "}}Brady 1973, p. 252. According to [[C.H.O'D. Alexander]]:Alexander 1972, p. 96 "This game was notable for two things. First, Fischer played the Queen's Gambit for the first time in his life in a serious game; second, he played it to perfection, the game indeed casting doubt on Black's whole opening system." The win gave Fischer the lead (3½–2½) for the first time in the match.Gligorić 1972, p. 54 {{clear}} ====Game 7: Spassky–Fischer, ½–½ (Sicilian Najdorf) {{anchor|Game 7}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 7''' | | | | | | | |rd | | | | | | | | | |pd| | | |pd| | | | | | | |nl| |pd |pl| |nd|rl|rl| |pd|pl | | | | | |kd| | | | |rd| | | | | | | | | | | |kl| |Final position after 49.Kg1 }} Spassky played 1.e4 for the first time in the match.Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 112 Fischer defended aggressively with his favorite Poisoned Pawn Variation of the Najdorf Sicilian, and after 17...Nc6 had the upper hand ([[Aivars Gipslis|Gipslis]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 489, n. 163 He consolidated his extra pawn and reached a winning [[chess endgame|endgame]], but then played carelessly, allowing Spassky to salvage a draw.Gligorić 1972, pp. 58–59 In the final position, Fischer had two extra pawns but had to execute a draw by {{chessgloss|perpetual check}} in order to escape being checkmated by Spassky's two rooks and knight.Gligorić 1972, p. 59 {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence, Najdorf Variation|Najdorf Variation]], [[Poisoned Pawn Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B97)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 a6 6.Bg5 e6 7.f4 Qb6 8.Qd2 Qxb2 9.Nb3 Qa3 10.Bd3 Be7 11.0-0 h6 12.Bh4 Nxe4 13.Nxe4 Bxh4 14.f5 exf5 15.Bb5+ axb5 16.Nxd6+ Kf8 17.Nxc8 Nc6 18.Nd6 Rd8 19.Nxb5 Qe7 20.Qf4 g6 21.a4 Bg5 22.Qc4 Be3+ 23.Kh1 f4 24.g3 g5 25.Rae1 Qb4 26.Qxb4+ Nxb4 27.Re2 Kg7 28.Na5 b6 29.Nc4 Nd5 30.Ncd6 Bc5 31.Nb7 Rc8 32.c4 Ne3 33.Rf3 Nxc4 34.gxf4 g4 35.Rd3 h5 36.h3 Na5 37.N7d6 Bxd6 38.Nxd6 Rc1+ 39.Kg2 Nc4 40.Ne8+ Kg6 41.h4 f6 42.Re6 Rc2+ 43.Kg1 Kf5 44.Ng7+ Kxf4 45.Rd4+ Kg3 46.Nf5+ Kf3 47.Ree4 Rc1+ 48.Kh2 Rc2+ 49.Kg1 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044728 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 7 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 8: Fischer–Spassky, 1–0 (English Symmetrical) {{anchor|Game 8}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 8''' | |rd| | | | |kd| | | | | |pd|pd|bd|pd |pd| | |pd| |nd|pd| |qd| | | | | | | | | |bd| | | | | | | |nl| | | |pl| |pl| | |ql|pl|pl|bl|pl | | |rl|rl| | |kl| |Spassky played 19...Nd7?? }} Fischer again played 1.c4; the game remained an English Opening rather than [[Transposition (chess)|transposing]] to another opening as in game 6. After 14...a6 the game was even.Matanović 1996 (Vol A), p. 285, n. 36 Spassky gave up an [[the exchange (chess)|exchange]] with 15...b5? for little [[compensation (chess)|compensation]] in the way of a positional advantage. It is unclear whether Spassky's 15th move was a sacrifice or a blunder, but his 19th move was definitely a blunder that lost a pawn and left him with a hopeless position. Fischer won, putting him ahead 5–3. {{block indent |1=[[English Opening]], [[English Opening#Symmetrical Defense|Symmetrical Defense]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' A39)
1.c4 c5 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 g6 5.Bg2 Bg7 6.0-0 0-0 7.d4 cxd4 8.Nxd4 Nxd4 9.Qxd4 d6 10.Bg5 Be6 11.Qf4 Qa5 12.Rac1 Rab8 13.b3 Rfc8 14.Qd2 a6 15.Be3 b5 16.Ba7 bxc4 17.Bxb8 Rxb8 18.bxc4 Bxc4 19.Rfd1 (''diagram'') Nd7 20.Nd5 Qxd2 21.Nxe7+ Kf8 22.Rxd2 Kxe7 23.Rxc4 Rb1+ 24.Bf1 Nc5 25.Kg2 a5 26.e4 Ba1 27.f4 f6 28.Re2 Ke6 29.Rec2 Bb2 30.Be2 h5 31.Rd2 Ba3 32.f5+ gxf5 33.exf5+ Ke5 34.Rcd4 Kxf5 35.Rd5+ Ke6 36.Rxd6+ Ke7 37.Rc6 1–0{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044367 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 8 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 9: Spassky–Fischer, ½–½ (QGD Semi-Tarrasch) {{anchor|Game 9}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 9''' |rd| |bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd |pd| | | | |pd|pd|pd | | |nd| |pd| | | | |pd| | | | | | | | |bl|pl|pl| | | | | | | | |nl| | |pl| | | | |pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql|kl| | |rl |Fischer's new move 9...b5! }} The game was delayed when Spassky took time off (pleading illness). The opening was the Semi-Tarrasch Defense of the Queen's Gambit Declined. Fischer played a {{chessgloss|theoretical novelty}} on the ninth move. After 13...0-0 the game was even ([[Bruno Parma|Parma]]),Matanović 1976 (Vol D), p. 197, n. 32 and the game ended in a quiet draw after just 29 moves. {{block indent |1=[[Queen's Gambit Declined]], [[Tarrasch Defense#Semi-Tarrasch Defense|Semi-Tarrasch Defense]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' D41)
1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3 c5 5.cxd5 Nxd5 6.e4 Nxc3 7.bxc3 cxd4 8.cxd4 Nc6 9.Bc4 b5 (''diagram'') 10.Bd3 Bb4+ 11.Bd2 Bxd2+ 12.Qxd2 a6 13.a4 0-0 14.Qc3 Bb7 15.axb5 axb5 16.0-0 Qb6 17.Rab1 b4 18.Qd2 Nxd4 19.Nxd4 Qxd4 20.Rxb4 Qd7 21.Qe3 Rfd8 22.Rfb1 Qxd3 23.Qxd3 Rxd3 24.Rxb7 g5 25.Rb8+ Rxb8 26.Rxb8+ Kg7 27.f3 Rd2 28.h4 h6 29.hxg5 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1128884 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 9 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 10: Fischer–Spassky, 1–0 (Ruy Lopez Breyer) {{anchor|Game 10}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 10''' |rd| | |rd| |bd|kd| | |bd| | | |pd|pd|pd |pd| | | | | | | |qd|pl|pd| | | | | | | | | |pl| | | | |bl| | | |nl| |pl | | | | | |pl|pl| | |rl|ql| |rl| |kl| |Position after 25...Qxa5{{chesspunc|?!}} 26.Bb3{{chesspunc|!}} }} Fischer played the [[Ruy Lopez]], an opening on which he was a great expert.Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 106 After 25...Qxa5{{chesspunc|?!}} (25...axb5!? 26.Rxb5 Ba6 gives Spassky a better chance; Gligorić), Fischer obtained the upper hand by initiating a dangerous attack on Spassky's king with 26.Bb3{{chesspunc|!}} ([[Aleksandar Matanović|Matanović]]),Matanović 1981 (Vol C), p. 466, n. 68 suddenly placing Black in a critical situation.Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 133Gligorić 1972, p. 71 Spassky sacrificed the exchange for a pawn, reaching a sharp endgame where his two [[Connected pawns|connected passed pawns]] gave almost sufficient compensation for Fischer's small {{chessgloss|material}} advantage.Byrne & Nei 1974, p. 134 Spassky had drawing chances, but played inexactly, and Fischer won the game with precise play.Byrne & Nei 1974, pp. 134–35 {{block indent |1=[[Ruy Lopez]], [[Ruy Lopez#Breyer Variation|Breyer Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' C95)
1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7 6.Re1 b5 7.Bb3 d6 8.c3 0-0 9.h3 Nb8 10.d4 Nbd7 11.Nbd2 Bb7 12.Bc2 Re8 13.b4 Bf8 14.a4 Nb6 15.a5 Nbd7 16.Bb2 Qb8 17.Rb1 c5 18.bxc5 dxc5 19.dxe5 Nxe5 20.Nxe5 Qxe5 21.c4 Qf4 22.Bxf6 Qxf6 23.cxb5 Red8 24.Qc1 Qc3 25.Nf3 Qxa5 26.Bb3 (''diagram'') axb5 27.Qf4 Rd7 28.Ne5 Qc7 29.Rbd1 Re7 30.Bxf7+ Rxf7 31.Qxf7+ Qxf7 32.Nxf7 Bxe4 33.Rxe4 Kxf7 34.Rd7+ Kf6 35.Rb7 Ra1+ 36.Kh2 Bd6+ 37.g3 b4 38.Kg2 h5 39.Rb6 Rd1 40.Kf3 Kf7 41.Ke2 Rd5 42.f4 g6 43.g4 hxg4 44.hxg4 g5 45.f5 Be5 46.Rb5 Kf6 47.Rexb4 Bd4 48.Rb6+ Ke5 49.Kf3 Rd8 50.Rb8 Rd7 51.R4b7 Rd6 52.Rb6 Rd7 53.Rg6 Kd5 54.Rxg5 Be5 55.f6 Kd4 56.Rb1 1–0{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1008423 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 10 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 11: Spassky–Fischer, 1–0 (Sicilian Najdorf) {{anchor|Game 11}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 11''' |rd| | | |kd|bd| |rd | |pd| |bd| |pd| | |pd| |nd|pd|pd|pd| | | | | | | | | |pd | | | | |pl|pl| | |qd|nl|nl| | | | | |pl| |pl|ql|bl| |pl|pl |rl| | | | |rl| |kl |Spassky played the extraordinary 14.Nb1{{chesspunc|!!}} }} This game was a dramatic win for Spassky, his first since games 1 and 2. As in game 7, Fischer essayed his favorite Poisoned Pawn Variation; Spassky surprised him with the startling 14.Nb1 (given {{chesspunc|!!}} by many annotators at the time), retreating the knight to its starting position.Mednis 1997, pp. 278–79 Although later analysis showed that the move was only sufficient for {{chessgloss|equality}} if Black responded correctly, Fischer did not.Mednis 1997, p. 279 If 15...Ne7!? by Black then 16.N1d2!? and the game is unclear ([[Aivars Gipslis|Gipslis]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 489, n. 158 After inferior defense by Fischer, Spassky trapped Fischer's queen and handed him his only defeat ever as Black in the Poisoned Pawn.{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chess.pl?yearcomp=exactly&year=&playercomp=black&pid=19233&player=&pid2=&player2=&movescomp=exactly&moves=&opening=&eco=B97&result= |title=Fischer games as Black in Poisoned Pawn |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=28 February 2009}} {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence, Najdorf Variation|Najdorf Variation]], [[Poisoned Pawn Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B97)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 a6 6.Bg5 e6 7.f4 Qb6 8.Qd2 Qxb2 9.Nb3 Qa3 10.Bxf6 gxf6 11.Be2 h5 12.0-0 Nc6 13.Kh1 Bd7 (''diagram'') 14.Nb1 Qb4 15.Qe3 d5 16.exd5 Ne7 17.c4 Nf5 18.Qd3 h4 19.Bg4 Nd6 20.N1d2 f5 21.a3 Qb6 22.c5 Qb5 23.Qc3 fxg4 24.a4 h3 25.axb5 hxg2+ 26.Kxg2 Rh3 27.Qf6 Nf5 28.c6 Bc8 29.dxe6 fxe6 30.Rfe1 Be7 31.Rxe6 1–0{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044724 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 11 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 12: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (QGD Orthodox) {{anchor|Game 12}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 12''' |rd|qd| | | |rd|kd| | |bd| |nd| |pd|pd| |pd| | | |pd|nd| |pd | | | | | | | | | |bd| |nl|bl| | |bl | | |nl| |pl| | | | |pl| | | |pl|pl|pl | | |rl|ql| |rl|kl| |Position after 19.Be4! Qb8! }} A quiet Queen's Gambit Declined. After 19.Be4!, Fischer had a slight advantage ([[Mikhail Yudovich|Yudovich]]),Matanović 1976 (Vol D), p. 289, n. 35 and after 24...a5 the game was even ([[Lev Polugaevsky|Polugaevsky]]).Matanović 1987 (Vol D), p. 354, n. 27 The game ended in an [[opposite-colored bishops endgame]] draw after 55 moves. {{block indent |1=[[Queen's Gambit Declined]], [[Queen's Gambit Declined#QGD Main Variations|Orthodox Defense]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' D66)
1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.d4 Nf6 4.Nc3 Be7 5.Bg5 h6 6.Bh4 0-0 7.e3 Nbd7 8.Rc1 c6 9.Bd3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 b5 11.Bd3 a6 12.a4 bxa4 13.Nxa4 Qa5 14.Nd2 Bb4 15.Nc3 c5 16.Nb3 Qd8 17.0-0 cxd4 18.Nxd4 Bb7 19.Be4 Qb8 (''diagram'') 20.Bg3 Qa7 21.Nc6 Bxc6 22.Bxc6 Rac8 23.Na4 Rfd8 24.Bf3 a5 25.Rc6 Rxc6 26.Bxc6 Rc8 27.Bf3 Qa6 28.h3 Qb5 29.Be2 Qc6 30.Bf3 Qb5 31.b3 Be7 32.Be2 Qb4 33.Ba6 Rc6 34.Bd3 Nc5 35.Qf3 Rc8 36.Nxc5 Bxc5 37.Rc1 Rd8 38.Bc4 Qd2 39.Rf1 Bb4 40.Bc7 Rd7 41.Qc6 Qc2 42.Be5 Rd2 43.Qa8+ Kh7 44.Bxf6 gxf6 45.Qf3 f5 46.g4 Qe4 47.Kg2 Kg6 48.Rc1 Ba3 49.Ra1 Bb4 50.Rc1 Be7 51.gxf5+ exf5 52.Re1 Rxf2+ 53.Kxf2 Bh4+ 54.Ke2 Qxf3+ 55.Kxf3 Bxe1 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044368 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 12 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 13: Spassky–Fischer, 0–1 (Alekhine's Defense) {{anchor|Game 13}}==== Fischer avoided the Sicilian Defense, with which he had lost game 11, opting for Alekhine's Defense. After 8...a5! 9.a4? (9.c3!? and Black is only slightly better; Gligorić) dxe5 10.dxe5 Na6! 11.0-0 Nc5, Fischer had the upper hand ([[Vladimir Bagirov|Bagirov]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 41, n. 82 The game swung one way, then another, and was finally adjourned at move 42 with Fischer having an edge in a sharp position but no clear win. The Soviet team's analysis convinced them that the position was drawn. Fischer stayed up until 8 a.m. analyzing it (the resumption being at 2:30 p.m.). He had not found a win either, but amazingly, he managed to set traps for Spassky, who fell into them and lost. Spassky's seconds were stunned, and Spassky himself refused to leave the board for a long time after the game was over, unable to believe the result. He remarked, "It is very strange. How can one lose with the opponent's only rook locked in completely at g8?" Lombardy noted the shock that Spassky was in after he resigned:[http://bobbyfischer.net/bobby07.html "A Mystery Wrapped in an Enigma"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150902042455/http://bobbyfischer.net/bobby07.html |date=2015-09-02 }} [[William Lombardy]], January 21, 1974, Bobby-Fischer.net

While Fischer dashed for his car, Spassky remained glued to his seat. A sympathetic Lothar Schmid came over, and the two shifted the pieces about with Boris demonstrating his careless mistakes. The two were left wondering how Bobby could have squeezed a win from a position which a night of competent analysis by a renowned Soviet team had showed to be a guaranteed draw.
{{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 13''' | | | | | |bl|rd| | | | | | | |pl| | | | | | | | | | |kd| | | |pd| | | |pd|pd| | | | | | | | | | | | |pd |pd| | |kl| | | | |rl| | | | | | | |Position after 61.Bf8 }} Former [[World Chess Champion|World Champion]] [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] said this game made a particularly strong impression on him. He called it "the highest creative achievement of Fischer". He resolved a {{chessgloss|drawish}} [[opposite-colored bishops endgame]] by sacrificing his bishop and trapping his own rook. "Then five [[passed pawn]]s struggled with the white rook. Nothing similar had been seen before in chess".Soltis 2003, p. 271 [[David Bronstein]] said, "Of all the games from the match, the 13th appeals to me most of all. When I play through the game I still cannot grasp the innermost motive behind this or that plan or even individual move. Like an enigma, it still teases my imagination."Plisetsky & Voronkov 2005, p. 359 {{block indent |1=[[Alekhine's Defense]], [[Alekhine's Defence#Modern Variation|Modern Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B04)
1.e4 Nf6 2.e5 Nd5 3.d4 d6 4.Nf3 g6 5.Bc4 Nb6 6.Bb3 Bg7 7.Nbd2 0-0 8.h3 a5 9.a4 dxe5 10.dxe5 Na6 11.0-0 Nc5 12.Qe2 Qe8 13.Ne4 Nbxa4 14.Bxa4 Nxa4 15.Re1 Nb6 16.Bd2 a4 17.Bg5 h6 18.Bh4 Bf5 19.g4 Be6 20.Nd4 Bc4 21.Qd2 Qd7 22.Rad1 Rfe8 23.f4 Bd5 24.Nc5 Qc8 25.Qc3 e6 26.Kh2 Nd7 27.Nd3 c5 28.Nb5 Qc6 29.Nd6 Qxd6 30.exd6 Bxc3 31.bxc3 f6 32.g5 hxg5 33.fxg5 f5 34.Bg3 Kf7 35.Ne5+ Nxe5 36.Bxe5 b5 37.Rf1 Rh8 38.Bf6 a3 39.Rf4 a2 40.c4 Bxc4 41.d7 Bd5 42.Kg3 Ra3+ 43.c3 Rha8 44.Rh4 e5 45.Rh7+ Ke6 46.Re7+ Kd6 47.Rxe5 Rxc3+ 48.Kf2 Rc2+ 49.Ke1 Kxd7 50.Rexd5+ Kc6 51.Rd6+ Kb7 52.Rd7+ Ka6 53.R7d2 Rxd2 54.Kxd2 b4 55.h4 Kb5 56.h5 c4 57.Ra1 gxh5 58.g6 h4 59.g7 h3 60.Be7 Rg8 61.Bf8 (''diagram'') h2 62.Kc2 Kc6 63.Rd1 b3+ 64.Kc3 h1=Q 65.Rxh1 Kd5 66.Kb2 f4 67.Rd1+ Ke4 68.Rc1 Kd3 69.Rd1+ Ke2 70.Rc1 f3 71.Bc5 Rxg7 72.Rxc4 Rd7 73.Re4+ Kf1 74.Bd4 f2 0–1{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1128889 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 13 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} When Spassky and Fischer shook hands, many in the audience thought they had agreed to a draw, thinking that 75.Rf4 draws. But 75...Rxd4! 76.Rxd4 Ke2 wins; 75.Be5 Rd1 76.Kxb3 Re1 also wins for Black.Soltis 2003, p. 275 The next seven games (games 14 through 20) were drawn. Fischer was unable to get the [[initiative (chess)|initiative]]. Spassky chose lines that Fischer was unable to break.Gligorić 1972, p. 116 With a three-point lead, Fischer was content to inch towards the title, and Spassky seemed resigned to his fate. The off-the-board antics continued, including a lawsuit against Fischer for damages by Chester Fox, who had filming rights to the match (Fischer had objected to what he said were noticeable camera noises, and the Icelandic hosts had reluctantly – they were to share in film revenues along with the two contestants – removed the television cameras), a Fischer demand to remove the first seven rows of spectators (eventually, three rows were cleared), and Soviet claims that Fischer was using electronic and chemical devices to 'control' Spassky, resulting in an Icelandic police sweep of the hall. {{clear}} ====Game 14: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (QGD Harrwitz) {{anchor|Game 14}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 14''' | | | | | |rd|kd| |pd|pd| | | |pd|pd| | |bd|nd| | |qd| |pd | | | |pd| | | | |ql| | | |nd|bl| | |pl| | | |pl|nl| | | |pl| | |bl|pl|pl|pl | | | | | |rl|kl| |Fischer played 21.Bb5? }} The game was postponed at Spassky's request. Fischer was again White in a Queen's Gambit Declined. After 18.Be5? (18.Nxb6 Qxb6 19.Be5 and Fischer keeps a slight advantage; Gligorić) Bxa4! 19.Qxa4 Nc6! Spassky had the upper hand ([[Anatoly Karpov|Karpov]]).Matanović 1987 (Vol D), p. 205, n. 88 Fischer played carelessly and lost a pawn on move 21. Spassky blundered it back on move 27, however, and the game settled into a 40-move draw.Gligorić 1972, pp. 87–89 {{block indent |1=[[Queen's Gambit Declined]], Harrwitz Attack (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' D37)
1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.d4 Nf6 4.Nc3 Be7 5.Bf4 0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Nc6 8.cxd5 exd5 9.Be2 Bxc5 10.0-0 Be6 11.Rc1 Rc8 12.a3 h6 13.Bg3 Bb6 14.Ne5 Ne7 15.Na4 Ne4 16.Rxc8 Bxc8 17.Nf3 Bd7 18.Be5 Bxa4 19.Qxa4 Nc6 20.Bf4 Qf6 (''diagram'') 21.Bb5 Qxb2 22.Bxc6 Nc3 23.Qb4 Qxb4 24.axb4 bxc6 25.Be5 Nb5 26.Rc1 Rc8 27.Nd4 f6 28.Bxf6 Bxd4 29.Bxd4 Nxd4 30.exd4 Rb8 31.Rxc6 Rxb4 32.Kf1 Rxd4 33.Ra6 Kf7 34.Rxa7+ Kf6 35.Rd7 h5 36.Ke2 g5 37.Ke3 Re4+ 38.Kd3 Ke6 39.Rg7 Kf6 40.Rd7 Ke6 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044369 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 14 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 15: Spassky–Fischer, ½–½ (Sicilian Najdorf) {{anchor|Game 15}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 15''' | | | |rd| | | | |kd|bd| | | | |ql| |pd| | | |pd| | | | | | | | | |nl| |pl| | | | | | | |kl| |pl| | | |pl| | |rl| | | | | |pl |qd| | | | | | | |Final position after 43...Qa1+ }} Fischer returned to the Najdorf Sicilian, but played the main line rather than the Poisoned Pawn Variation with which he had lost game 11. At move 13, Fischer sacrificed a pawn for {{chessgloss|counterplay}}, which Spassky accepted. After 19.c3, Spassky had the upper hand ([[Aivars Gipslis|Gipslis]]).Matanović 1997 (Vol B), p. 539, n. 48 After 28...Rd7 the game was even, but when Spassky took a second pawn with 29.Qxh5?! it allowed Fischer a very strong attack.Gligorić, pp. 92–93 Spassky, on the brink of disaster, "found miraculous replies while in time pressure" and Fischer was only able to achieve a draw by [[threefold repetition]] after 43 moves.Gligorić 1972, pp. 90–91 Two years later, Yugoslav grandmaster [[Dragoljub Velimirović]] improved on Spassky's play with the piece sacrifice 13.Bxb5!?, winning a crushing victory in Velimirović–Al Kazzaz, Nice Olympiad 1974.[[Raymond Keene]] and [[David Levy (chess player)|David Levy]], ''The 1974 World Chess Olympiad'', R.H.M. Press, 1975, p. 34, {{ISBN|978-0-89058-205-3}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1291249 |title=Velimirović vs. Al Kazzaz, Nice Olympiad 1974 (1–0, 28) |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=5 March 2009}}See also {{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1014982 |title=Gunawan vs. Adianto, Indonesia 1983 (1–0, 31) |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=5 March 2009}} But see {{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1468818 |title=Anderson vs. Gormally, British Championship 2007 (0–1, 73) |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=5 March 2009}} Black in turn later improved on Fischer's 12...0-0-0 with 12...b4.[[Nick de Firmian]], ''[[Modern Chess Openings]]'' (15th ed. 2008), Random House Puzzles & Games, p. 255, {{ISBN|978-0-8129-3682-7}} {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence, Najdorf Variation|Najdorf Variation]], [[Sicilian Defence, Najdorf Variation#Classical Main line|Classical Main line]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B99)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 a6 6.Bg5 e6 7.f4 Be7 8.Qf3 Qc7 9.0-0-0 Nbd7 10.Bd3 b5 11.Rhe1 Bb7 12.Qg3 0-0-0 13.Bxf6 Nxf6 14.Qxg7 Rdf8 15.Qg3 b4 16.Na4 Rhg8 17.Qf2 Nd7 18.Kb1 Kb8 19.c3 Nc5 20.Bc2 bxc3 21.Nxc3 Bf6 22.g3 h5 23.e5 dxe5 24.fxe5 Bh8 25.Nf3 Rd8 26.Rxd8+ Rxd8 27.Ng5 Bxe5 28.Qxf7 Rd7 29.Qxh5 Bxc3 30.bxc3 Qb6+ 31.Kc1 Qa5 32.Qh8+ Ka7 33.a4 Nd3+ 34.Bxd3 Rxd3 35.Kc2 Rd5 36.Re4 Rd8 37.Qg7 Qf5 38.Kb3 Qd5+ 39.Ka3 Qd2 40.Rb4 Qc1+ 41.Rb2 Qa1+ 42.Ra2 Qc1+ 43.Rb2 Qa1+ ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044730 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 15 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 16: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (Ruy Lopez Exchange) {{anchor|Game 16}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 16''' | |rd| | | | | | | | |pd| | |kd|pd|pd |pd| |pd| | | | | | | | | |bd| | | | | |pd| |rd| | | | | | | |bl| |pl| |pl|pl|rl|rl| |pl|kl|pl | | | | | | | | |Play continued 22...Rxb2! 23.Kf3! }} Fischer played the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez, a favorite line of his.[[Larry Kaufman]], ''The Chess Advantage in Black and White'', Random House Puzzles & Games, 2004, pp. 4–5, {{ISBN|978-0-8129-3571-4}} After 17...Rfe8 the game was equal ([[Aivars Gipslis|Gipslis]]).Matanović 1981 (Vol C), p. 327, n. 83 Spassky defended well, and after a [[chess tactics|tactical]] flurry in the [[chess endgame|endgame]], ended up with the nominal advantage of an extra pawn in a rook ending known to be an easy {{chessgloss|book draw}}.Gligorić 1972, pp. 96–98 Although a draw could have been agreed after move 34,Gligorić 1972, p. 99 Spassky "used his symbolic {{chessgloss|material}} advantage for a little psychological torture", prolonging the game until move 60 before agreeing to a draw.Gligorić 1972, p. 96 {{block indent |1=[[Ruy Lopez]], [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation|Exchange Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' C69)
1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Bxc6 dxc6 5.0-0 f6 6.d4 Bg4 7.dxe5 Qxd1 8.Rxd1 fxe5 9.Rd3 Bd6 10.Nbd2 Nf6 11.Nc4 Nxe4 12.Ncxe5 Bxf3 13.Nxf3 0-0 14.Be3 b5 15.c4 Rab8 16.Rc1 bxc4 17.Rd4 Rfe8 18.Nd2 Nxd2 19.Rxd2 Re4 20.g3 Be5 21.Rcc2 Kf7 22.Kg2 (''diagram'') Rxb2 23.Kf3 c3 24.Kxe4 cxd2 25.Rxd2 Rb5 26.Rc2 Bd6 27.Rxc6 Ra5 28.Bf4 Ra4+ 29.Kf3 Ra3+ 30.Ke4 Rxa2 31.Bxd6 cxd6 32.Rxd6 Rxf2 33.Rxa6 Rxh2 34.Kf3 Rd2 35.Ra7+ Kf6 36.Ra6+ Ke7 37.Ra7+ Rd7 38.Ra2 Ke6 39.Kg2 Re7 40.Kh3 Kf6 41.Ra6+ Re6 42.Ra5 h6 43.Ra2 Kf5 44.Rf2+ Kg5 45.Rf7 g6 46.Rf4 h5 47.Rf3 Rf6 48.Ra3 Re6 49.Rf3 Re4 50.Ra3 Kh6 51.Ra6 Re5 52.Kh4 Re4+ 53.Kh3 Re7 54.Kh4 Re5 55.Rb6 Kg7 56.Rb4 Kh6 57.Rb6 Re1 58.Kh3 Rh1+ 59.Kg2 Ra1 60.Kh3 Ra4 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044370 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 16 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 17: Spassky–Fischer, ½–½ (Pirc Defense) {{anchor|Game 17}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 17''' |rd| | | | |rd|kd| |pd|pd| | |pd|pd| |pd | | |nd|pd| |nd|pd| | | | | | |pl| | | | | | |pl| |bd| | |bl|qd| |bl|nl| | |pl| |pl| |ql| |pl|pl | | | |rl| |rl|kl| |Position after 15.f5! Nf6! }} Fischer played the Pirc Defense for the first time in his career.Gligorić 1972, p. 102 After 18...Qc7 the game was unclear ([[Bruno Parma|Parma]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 81, n. 32 The game ended in a draw by the threefold repetition rule.Alexander 1972, p. 132 {{block indent |1=[[Pirc Defense]], [[Pirc Defence, Austrian Attack|Austrian Attack]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B09)
1.e4 d6 2.d4 g6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.f4 Bg7 5.Nf3 c5 6.dxc5 Qa5 7.Bd3 Qxc5 8.Qe2 0-0 9.Be3 Qa5 10.0-0 Bg4 11.Rad1 Nc6 12.Bc4 Nh5 13.Bb3 Bxc3 14.bxc3 Qxc3 15.f5 Nf6 (''diagram'') 16.h3 Bxf3 17.Qxf3 Na5 18.Rd3 Qc7 19.Bh6 Nxb3 20.cxb3 Qc5+ 21.Kh1 Qe5 22.Bxf8 Rxf8 23.Re3 Rc8 24.fxg6 hxg6 25.Qf4 Qxf4 26.Rxf4 Nd7 27.Rf2 Ne5 28.Kh2 Rc1 29.Ree2 Nc6 30.Rc2 Re1 31.Rfe2 Ra1 32.Kg3 Kg7 33.Rcd2 Rf1 34.Rf2 Re1 35.Rfe2 Rf1 36.Re3 a6 37.Rc3 Re1 38.Rc4 Rf1 39.Rdc2 Ra1 40.Rf2 Re1 41.Rfc2 g5 42.Rc1 Re2 43.R1c2 Re1 44.Rc1 Re2 45.R1c2 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044731 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 17 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 18: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (Sicilian Rauzer) {{anchor|Game 18}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 18''' | |rd| | | | | | | | |kd|bd|bd| | | | | | |pd|pd|pd| | |rd| | | | | | |pd |pd| |qd|nl|pl| | | |pl|pd|pl|nl| | |pl| | |pl| | |ql|rl| |pl |kl| | | |rl| | | |Position after 31.Rf2 }} The game opened with a Richter–Rauzer Attack. After 19...Ne5 the game was equal ([[Aleksandar Matanović|Matanović]], Ugrinović).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), pp. 336–37, n. 9 Like game 17, the game ended in a draw by threefold repetition. {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence#Classical Variation|Richter–Rauzer Attack]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B69)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 d6 3.Nc3 Nc6 4.d4 cxd4 5.Nxd4 Nf6 6.Bg5 e6 7.Qd2 a6 8.0-0-0 Bd7 9.f4 Be7 10.Nf3 b5 11.Bxf6 gxf6 12.Bd3 Qa5 13.Kb1 b4 14.Ne2 Qc5 15.f5 a5 16.Nf4 a4 17.Rc1 Rb8 18.c3 b3 19.a3 Ne5 20.Rhf1 Nc4 21.Bxc4 Qxc4 22.Rce1 Kd8 23.Ka1 Rb5 24.Nd4 Ra5 25.Nd3 Kc7 26.Nb4 h5 27.g3 Re5 28.Nd3 Rb8 29.Qe2 Ra5 30.fxe6 fxe6 31.Rf2 (''diagram'') e5 32.Nf5 Bxf5 33.Rxf5 d5 34.exd5 Qxd5 35.Nb4 Qd7 36.Rxh5 Bxb4 37.cxb4 Rd5 38.Rc1+ Kb7 39.Qe4 Rc8 40.Rb1 Kb6 41.Rh7 Rd4 42.Qg6 Qc6 43.Rf7 Rd6 44.Qh6 Qf3 45.Qh7 Qc6 46.Qh6 Qf3 47.Qh7 Qc6 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044371 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 18 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 19: Spassky–Fischer, ½–½ (Alekhine's Defense) {{anchor|Game 19}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 19''' |rd|nd| | | |rd|kd| |pd| | | | |pd|pd|pd | | |pd| |pd| | | |qd| |pl|nl|pl| |bd| | | | |pl|pl| | | | | | | | |bl| |pl |pl| | | | | |pl| |rl| | |ql| |rl|kl| |Position after 18.Nxd5! Bg5! }} The second Alekhine's Defense of the match, the game ended in a draw after 40 moves. After 18...Bg5!, Gligorić commented "a queer situation has arisen with many tactical possibilities for both sides."Gligorić 1972, p. 114 After 19.Bh5 the position was unclear ([[Vladimir Bagirov|Bagirov]]).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 48, n. 113 After 37...a6, C.H.O'D. Alexander wrote: "A miracle; after all the excitements – two piece sacrifices by White and the counter-sacrifice of a rook by Black – the players have reached a completely equal endgame with no chances for either side."Alexander 1972, p. 135 {{block indent |1=[[Alekhine's Defense]], [[Alekhine's Defence#Modern Variation|Modern Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B05)
1.e4 Nf6 2.e5 Nd5 3.d4 d6 4.Nf3 Bg4 5.Be2 e6 6.0-0 Be7 7.h3 Bh5 8.c4 Nb6 9.Nc3 0-0 10.Be3 d5 11.c5 Bxf3 12.Bxf3 Nc4 13.b3 Nxe3 14.fxe3 b6 15.e4 c6 16.b4 bxc5 17.bxc5 Qa5 18.Nxd5 Bg5 (''diagram'') 19.Bh5 cxd5 20.Bxf7+ Rxf7 21.Rxf7 Qd2 22.Qxd2 Bxd2 23.Raf1 Nc6 24.exd5 exd5 25.Rd7 Be3+ 26.Kh1 Bxd4 27.e6 Be5 28.Rxd5 Re8 29.Re1 Rxe6 30.Rd6 Kf7 31.Rxc6 Rxc6 32.Rxe5 Kf6 33.Rd5 Ke6 34.Rh5 h6 35.Kh2 Ra6 36.c6 Rxc6 37.Ra5 a6 38.Kg3 Kf6 39.Kf3 Rc3+ 40.Kf2 Rc2+ ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044726 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 19 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 20: Fischer–Spassky, ½–½ (Sicilian Rauzer) {{anchor|Game 20}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Fischer–Spassky, game 20''' | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |kd| | |bd| | |pd| | |pd| | |pd |pd| | |nd| | |pd| |pl| |kl| |nl| |pl| | |pl|pl| | | | |pl | | | | |nl| | | |Final position after 54...Nd4 }} Another Richter–Rauzer, after 13...Nxd2 the game was equal ([[Aleksandar Matanović|Matanović]], Ugrinović).Matanović 1984 (Vol B), p. 335, n. 12 Fischer was unable to make progress and Spassky got a better position. Fischer headed for a {{chessgloss|drawish}} [[chess endgame|endgame]] but Spassky twice avoided a draw by threefold repetition. After 54 moves, Fischer made an incorrect claim of threefold repetition, but Spassky agreed to a draw anyway.Gligorić 1972, p. 119 See [[Threefold repetition#Fischer versus Spassky]]. {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence#Classical Variation|Richter–Rauzer Attack]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B68)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nf6 5.Nc3 d6 6.Bg5 e6 7.Qd2 a6 8.0-0-0 Bd7 9.f4 Be7 10.Be2 0-0 11.Bf3 h6 12.Bh4 Nxe4 13.Bxe7 Nxd2 14.Bxd8 Nxf3 15.Nxf3 Rfxd8 16.Rxd6 Kf8 17.Rhd1 Ke7 18.Na4 Be8 19.Rxd8 Rxd8 20.Nc5 Rb8 21.Rd3 a5 22.Rb3 b5 23.a3 a4 24.Rc3 Rd8 25.Nd3 f6 26.Rc5 Rb8 27.Rc3 g5 28.g3 Kd6 29.Nc5 g4 30.Ne4+ Ke7 31.Ne1 Rd8 32.Nd3 Rd4 33.Nef2 h5 34.Rc5 Rd5 35.Rc3 Nd4 36.Rc7+ Rd7 37.Rxd7+ Bxd7 38.Ne1 e5 39.fxe5 fxe5 40.Kd2 Bf5 41.Nd1 Kd6 42.Ne3 Be6 43.Kd3 Bf7 44.Kc3 Kc6 45.Kd3 Kc5 46.Ke4 Kd6 47.Kd3 Bg6+ 48.Kc3 Kc5 49.Nd3+ Kd6 50.Ne1 Kc6 51.Kd2 Kc5 52.Nd3+ Kd6 53.Ne1 Ne6 54.Kc3 Nd4 ½–½{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1044372 |title=Fischer vs. Spassky, Reykjavik 1972, rd 20 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} {{clear}} ====Game 21: Spassky–Fischer, 0–1 (Sicilian Taimanov) {{anchor|Game 21}}==== {{Chess diagram |tright |'''Spassky–Fischer, game 21''' | | | | | | | | | | | |bl| | | | | | | | | |pd| | | | | | | |pl| |pd |pl| | | | |kd| | | |pl| | | | | | |rd| | | | |pl|kl| | | | | | | | | |The final move, Spassky {{chessgloss|sealed move|sealed}} 41.Be6–d7? }} This game turned out to be the last game. Fischer used a line of the Sicilian that he had never before played as Black, and further surprised Spassky with a novelty on move eight.Byrne & Nei 1974, pp. 207–08 After 14...Qxf6 the game was equal ([[Mark Taimanov|Taimanov]]).Matanović 1997 (Vol B), p. 279, n. 31 Spassky played badly in the [[Chess endgame|endgame]] and the game was adjourned with a big advantage for Fischer. However, Fischer's 40th move was not the best; he should have played 40...Kg4! before ...h5 (his actual 40th move). Had Spassky [[sealed move|sealed]] 41.Kh3! (preventing ...Kg4), he would have had drawing chances. However, his 41.Bd7? would have allowed Black to win with 41...Kg4 followed by pushing his h-pawn.Gligorić 1972, p. 123 On September 1, the day scheduled for resumption of the game, arbiter Lothar Schmid informed Fischer and the audience that Spassky had resigned the game by telephone, making Fischer the winner of the match.Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, pp. 192–93 Euwe expressed disappointment that Spassky had not arrived at the playing hall to congratulate Fischer in person.Andrew Torchia, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=19720901&id=ovArAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EGkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1155,13376&hl=en Fischer is Crowned World Chess Champ], Associated Press, September 1, 1972 {{block indent |1=[[Sicilian Defense]], [[Sicilian Defence#Paulsen Variation|Paulsen Variation]], transposing to [[Sicilian Defence#Taimanov Variation|Taimanov Variation]] (''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' B46)
1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 a6 5.Nc3 Nc6 6.Be3 Nf6 7.Bd3 d5 8.exd5 exd5 9.0-0 Bd6 10.Nxc6 bxc6 11.Bd4 0-0 12.Qf3 Be6 13.Rfe1 c5 14.Bxf6 Qxf6 15.Qxf6 gxf6 16.Rad1 Rfd8 17.Be2 Rab8 18.b3 c4 19.Nxd5 Bxd5 20.Rxd5 Bxh2+ 21.Kxh2 Rxd5 22.Bxc4 Rd2 23.Bxa6 Rxc2 24.Re2 Rxe2 25.Bxe2 Rd8 26.a4 Rd2 27.Bc4 Ra2 28.Kg3 Kf8 29.Kf3 Ke7 30.g4 f5 31.gxf5 f6 32.Bg8 h6 33.Kg3 Kd6 34.Kf3 Ra1 35.Kg2 Ke5 36.Be6 Kf4 37.Bd7 Rb1 38.Be6 Rb2 39.Bc4 Ra2 40.Be6 h5 41.Bd7 0–1{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1008424 |title=Spassky vs. Fischer, Reykjavik 1972, rd 21 |website=[[Chessgames.com]] |accessdate=8 April 2018 }}}} The final score was 12½–8½ in favor of Fischer, making him the eleventh World Champion. Spassky won three games (including the forfeit in game 2), Fischer won seven games, and there were eleven draws.Roberts, Schonberg, Horowitz & Reshevsky 1972, p. 194 {{clear}} ==Aftermath== Fischer's crushing victory made him an instant celebrity. Upon his return to New York,Soltis 2003, pp. 10–11. a Bobby Fischer Day was held."Wearing city's gold medal and accompanied by Mayor [[John Lindsay]], Bobby shakes hands with some 3,000 fans attending..." Saidy & Lessing 1974, photo on pp. 224–25; captions on p. 227. He was offered numerous product endorsement offers worth "at least $5 million", all of which he declined.Larry Evans, in Müller 2009, p. 13. He appeared on the cover of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''{{cite web |url=https://www.si.com/vault/issue/43123/1/1 |title=BOBBY'S CHESSBOARD MASTERY |work=Sports Illustrated |date=August 14, 1972 |accessdate=May 12, 2007 }} with American Olympic swimming champion [[Mark Spitz]]. Fischer also made an appearance on a [[Bob Hope]] TV special.{{cite news |last=Cavett|first=Dick |url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/02/08/was-it-only-a-game/?_r=0 |title=Was It Only a Game? |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=February 8, 2008 |accessdate=January 4, 2014}} But the games in this match proved to be his last public competitive games for several decades. Fischer had, prior to the match, felt that the first-to-12½-points format was not fair, since it encouraged whoever was leading to play for draws instead of wins. He himself adopted this strategy in the match: after having taken a comfortable lead, he drew games 14–20. With each game, he coasted closer to the title, while Spassky lost a chance to fight back. This style of chess offended Fischer. Instead he demanded the format be changed to that used in the very [[World Chess Championship 1886|first World Chess Championship]], between [[Wilhelm Steinitz]] and [[Johannes Zukertort]], where the winner was the first player to score 10 wins, with draws not counting. In case of a 9–9 score, the champion would retain title, and the prize fund split equally.{{cite book |last=Seirawan |first=Yasser |date= |title=Winning Chess Brilliancies |url= |location= |publisher=Microsoft Press |page= |isbn=978-1857443479}}{{cite book |last=Kasparov |first=Garry |date= |title=My Great Predecessors, Volume IV |url= |location= |publisher=Gloucester Publishers |page= |isbn=1-85744-395-0}} A FIDE Congress was held in 1974 during the [[Nice, France|Nice]] [[Chess Olympiad|Olympiad]]. The delegates voted in favor of Fischer's 10-win proposal, but rejected the 9–9 clause as well as the possibility of an unlimited match.Plisetsky & Voronkov 2005, pp. 412–13 In response, Fischer refused to defend his title. [[Anatoly Karpov]], who had fought his way through the [[World Chess Championship 1975|1975 candidates tournament]], was declared World Champion by forfeit. Seventeen years later, Fischer entered negotiations with sponsors willing to fund a match under his proposed format, settling on a bid from Yugoslav millionaire [[Jezdimir Vasiljević]]. Fischer insisted that since he had not been defeated in a match, he was still the true World Champion. He further claimed that all the games in the FIDE-sanctioned World Championship matches, involving Karpov and his challengers [[Viktor Korchnoi|Korchnoi]] and [[Garry Kasparov|Kasparov]], had prearranged outcomes.{{cite web |last=Weeks|first=Mark |url=http://www.mark-weeks.com/chess/92fs$$.htm |title=1992 Fischer – Spassky Rematch Highlights |publisher=Printer |date=1997–2008 |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} He then challenged Spassky (tied for 96th–102nd on the FIDE rating list at the time) to a rematch, leading to the [[Fischer–Spassky (1992 match)|1992 Fischer–Spassky match]]. ==In popular culture== * The musical ''[[Chess (musical)|Chess]]'', with lyrics by [[Tim Rice]] and music by [[Björn Ulvaeus]] and [[Benny Andersson]], tells the story of two chess champions, referred to only as "The American" and "The Russian". The musical is loosely based on the 1972 World Championship match between Fischer and Spassky.[[William Hartston]], ''Chess: The Making of the Musical'', Pavilion Books, 1986, p. 10. {{ISBN|1-85145-006-8}}. * During the 1972 Fischer–Spassky match, the Soviet [[bard (Soviet Union)|bard]] [[Vladimir Vysotsky]] wrote an ironic two-song cycle "Honor of the Chess Crown". The first song is about a rank-and-file Soviet worker's preparation for the match with Fischer; the second is about the game. Many expressions from the songs have become [[catchphrase]]s in Russian culture.{{cite web |last=Zhaskyran|first=Musin |url=http://www.kulichki.com/vv/ovys/articles/0018.html |title=Chess Problems (about chess songs of Vladimir Vysotsky) |date=January 2001 |accessdate=January 29, 2014|language=ru}} * The 2014 film ''[[Pawn Sacrifice]]'' tells the story of Fischer's attempts to defeat Russian Boris Spassky and become the World Champion. The film is directed by [[Edward Zwick]] and stars [[Tobey Maguire]] as Fischer and [[Liev Schreiber]] as Spassky. * In the sixth episode of season 3 of [[Drunk History]], comedian [[Rich Fulcher]] recounts the 1972 World Championship match between Fischer and Spassky. {{cite episode |title=Games |series=Drunk History |date=6 October 2015 |url=http://www.cc.com/episodes/4vpgrn/drunk-history-games-season-3-ep-309 |network=Comedy Central |season=3 |number=6 }} ==See also== * [[Fischer–Spassky (1992 match)]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book |last=Alexander |first=C.H.O'D. |authorlink=Conel Hugh O'Donel Alexander |title=Fischer v.
